organization: National Science and Technology Development Agency (NSTDA)
description: NSTDA was established to promote science and technology development in Thailand. Early computing infrastructure was developed to support research activities across various scientific disciplines.

Major universities began establishing dedicated computing centers to support research in engineering, sciences, and computational studies. These early systems laid the foundation for advanced computing in Thailand.

Thailand launched its first national grid computing initiative, connecting multiple universities and research institutions to share computational resources and collaborate on large-scale research projects. NECTEC played a key role in coordinating this early grid infrastructure.
Government initiative to establish advanced computing infrastructure to support national research priorities including biotechnology, materials science, and environmental studies.

Establishment of the National e-Science Infrastructure Consortium under NECTEC to coordinate and develop e-Science infrastructure across Thailand. This consortium became a cornerstone for national research computing coordination.

Development of comprehensive e-Science infrastructure including high-performance computing resources, data storage systems, and network connectivity to support national research programs. The consortium provided HPC services and grid computing capabilities.
Major upgrade of HPC infrastructure with modern multi-core processors, GPU accelerators, and high-speed interconnects to support emerging computational science applications.

Official establishment of ThaiSC as Thailand's national supercomputing center, marking a significant milestone in the country's HPC development. ThaiSC was founded to provide cutting-edge HPC services for national R&D community.

Deployment of LANTA, Thailand's flagship supercomputer with 31,744 CPU cores and 704 NVIDIA A100 GPUs. LANTA supports bioinformatics, simulations, weather forecasting, and AI research across the nation.
Major universities deployed dedicated HPC systems including ERAWAN at CMU and APEX at CMKL University, expanding Thailand's distributed HPC ecosystem for specialized research applications.

Integration of artificial intelligence capabilities with HPC infrastructure across universities and research centers, including systems at Kasetsart University (KU Nontri AI) and Mahidol University (MU-AI Center).
Deployment of 'The Crust 2.5' by PTTEP, marking significant private sector investment in HPC with 47,360 CPU cores and ~512 NVIDIA H100 GPUs for exploration and production applications.

organization: Prince of Songkla University, Khon Kaen University
description: Expansion of HPC infrastructure to regional universities including PSU-Singkhorn in the south and KKU systems in the northeast, creating a truly national HPC network.

Thailand's roadmap for next-generation HPC includes exascale computing capabilities, quantum-classical hybrid systems, and sustainable computing infrastructure to support national digital transformation.
